posts.subject: upnp daemon for redhat/CentOS?
posts.body:
Hello, in order to become more accessible to the peers of the P2P networks, i wast told i should setup upnp on my OpenVPN server which i am using to connect the internet.

When googling for "set up upnp on openvpn server" i have found tutorials like [this](https://www.hackviking.com/single-board-computers/pi-make-a-vpn-gateway-with-upnp-port-forwarding/ ) and [this](https://wiki.celogeek.com/pages/Tutorials:OpenVPN_with_uPNP_support_in_10_minutes), both are for debian/ubuntu:
apt-get install linux-igd
But i have CentOS (Redhat based, yum package manager).

Please any idea which package/upnp daemon to install so it works similar way like linux-igd?
Someone suggested "gupnp-igd" but it is just a library. not daemon, so i guess i can not use it.
I assume if i am unable to find any, i will have to manually setup forwarding as mentioned in one of the tutorials.

Update: i tried manual forwarding and also to setup linux-igd on Debian, but none worked to make me Active on torrent trackers or to have port open at https://www.yougetsignal.com/tools/open-ports/

posts.subject: Full disk encryption on Linux
posts.body:
Hello,

in Windows 10 i benefit from full disk encryption done by the [TrueCrypt](https://truecrypt.ch)

Last time i installed LUbuntu i was able to encrypt only my user folder i guess. Is there any simple way/tutorial/distibution you can recommend which support full system disk encryption?

What do you think about full disk encryption in Linux? Thank you :)

UPDATE: i see VeraCrypt is very similar to Truecrypt, so once Linux is installed (without encryption; i have not seen an option for the full disk encryption using dmcrypt) [VeraCrypt can be run to encrypt system drive](http://www.elinuxbook.com/install-veracrypt-linux-full-disk-encryption-in-ubuntu-16-04-a-best-truecrypt-alternative-for-linux/) i assume.

For more advanced command line setup, check  [here](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Dm-crypt/Encrypting_an_entire_system) though that one is too hard for me to understand.

>>4c5c3ddd-23a6-46fc-a2a0-856871dcc238
Web browsers may have some internal page which shows the performance needed by various browser tabs. Firefox has page:
about:performance
about:memory
Best way to prevent miners and various tracking/ad scripts is to install ad blocker plugin to your browser (i use uBlock Origin).
Regarding DDoS attack caused by a bad zite, to prevent this, i think one should use some browser extension that blocks clearnet connections while one is on zeronet site (127.0.0.1:43110), i think someone was asking this on zerohello or zerome when you do a search.. One way to do it may be to use some plugin that filters web pages requests. Maybe something like Ublock Origin or uMatrix - and [compose some custom rule which will block all non 127.0.0.1 requests when being on 127.0.0.1 page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1DJEfWgdJ3rGnqCrKwLrBdQGodRaEBkAry:zeronet:e81476ed-a373-466a-bb36-0946b39a6d5c). Or finding some browser setting that limits number of connections you can do - i bet browsers already have such limit (duck.com - limit number of connections web browser make page load) so hopefuly nothing to worry about regarding ddos from a zite. Third thing to do is to anonymize your traffic (Tor, VPN) so even if you do some attack, you are anonymous. Maybe there are browser extensions which shows performance impact of the browser tab. i used one in Firefox ESR.

It remind me to appreaciate what internet i have. Once ISPs make cheaper mobile internet, i am planning to buy it in order to [keep better connectivity with 2 internets](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1527007067_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Dual+WAN+routers+for+internet+connectivity+load+balancing+failover).
If you are from India and money is not n issue, i have seen there are devices that can be used to connect multiple USB dongles of multiple ISPs so you may join multiple internets for better speed and uptime.

To Migrate Millchan uploaded/downloaded data like images i think one have to quit Zeronet on both devices, backup millchan zeronet folder on both devices. (pathToYour/ZeroNet/data/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/), then delete the folder on the new device and copy it from old device to new device.

posts.subject: Is it wrong i do not want to owe someone by receiving their gifts?
posts.body:
Hello,

my father is living with a woman that is not my mother without mariage.

Problem is that when receiving something from people (food, products of work, electricity) that are not part of my family i feel like a parasite or that i am beginning to owe them "something" and i do not have quite anything to give, except money, but that would not be polite. I can express thanks to them (which may be treated as a gift too), but i do not feel it to be enough. I have problem with this that makes it more dificult to be with non family people. Please what are your advises regarding this? Moreover my problem is that i am not a good company, because my world view is rather pessimistic and i usually do not have common interests with people and i am rather speechless. Thank you

thanks, i mean receiving from non-family people in general. i read someone say that simply one should repeat to oneself "i owe nothing", but thanks for the advice buying a gifts for such people who are themself giving the gifts.

When thinking about this, i think what is rewarding for the gifth givers is if the recipient (except from appreciation) is showing their personal interest in the giver by asking questions ( i.e. [small talk](https://www.google.com/search?q=small+talk+examples+showing+interest&oq=small+talk+examples+showing+interest) )

posts.subject: Windows vs Linux - CPU and RAM usage
posts.body:
Currently i am on Windows 10, i am bothered by the:

- 30% CPU usage of the qBittorrent (torrent client)
- 15% CPU usage of the iddle Firefox
- 10% CPU usage of the other two P2P apps

posts.subject: Is there Linux "grep" alternative for Windows?
posts.body:
When i used " | grep" command to filter out results of a command in Windows command line Window 10, then i received:
'grep' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

Someone recommended https://cygwin.com/install.html, but when i launch its exe (cygwin-console-helper.exe), it does nothing. Another advise was to use Windows PowerShell, but i do not think i have it. (have outdated Win.)

Thank you, indeed. It worked.

#Linux
$ ls -ls | grep mkyong

#Windows
c:\> dir | findstr mkyong
___________
#Linux
$ ls -ls | grep -iE "mkyong|music"

#Windows
c:\> dir | findstr -i "mkyong music"
___________
#Linux 
$ grep mkyong test.txt

#Windows
c:\> findstr mkyong test.txt
___________
#Linux
$ grep mkyong -lr /path/folder

#Windows
c:\> findstr /M mkyong c:\folder\*
___________
findstr -?

posts.body:
Here's how the European political groups voted on #uploadfilters today (#Article13, Voss' proposal). Total: 366 in favour, 297 against.

[Data](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-%2f%2fEP%2f%2fNONSGML%2bPV%2b20180912%2bRES-RCV%2bDOC%2bPDF%2bV0%2f%2fEN&language=EN)
[Details about Article 13](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1528386725_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/)

"The Parliament will now enter into final negotiations with the Council, representing the member state governments. ... Directive may well still be rejected when it comes up for a final vote right before next year’s European elections."

[source: Julia Reda - Pirate party MEP](https://twitter.com/Senficon)
[Freedom not Fear 2018](https://aktion.digitalcourage.de/fnf2018) - Four days of protests, workshops, discussions, meetings (From 21 to 24 September 2018 in Brussels)

It appears that the upload filters (Article 13) will apply only on big enterprises which will need to analyze user uploaded content and if the robot think it is copyrighted, it will not allow publishing of the content.

Will be MEMEs (parody) censored/filtered out after EU copyright directive/article 13 (upload filters that will need to be used by big enterprises) is in effect?

The ICT lawyer says: "Memes can in some cases - but not always - fall under the parody exception. Even if a meme fall under an exception it could still be catched by a filter that a service provider think it needs to have to limit its liability under article 13."
I think that the image recognition systems can quite precisely detect what is MEME. (large text with usually similar font on the image)

posts.subject: [tutorial] Swappiness kernel parameter
posts.body:
Hello, If i increase swappiness to lets say 90, then the system will tend to keep more data in memory (RAM+SWAP) (it will not be removing data from swap too "aggressively")?

the Wikipedia says about swappiness this:

> "Swappiness is a Linux kernel parameter that controls the relative weight given to swapping out of runtime memory, as opposed to dropping pages from the system page cache. Swappiness can be set to values between 0 and 100 inclusive. A low value causes the kernel to avoid swapping; a higher value causes the kernel to try to use swap space. The default value is 60;"

__TEMPORARILY SET SWAPPINESS:__

# Set the swappiness value as root
echo 10 > /proc/sys/vm/swappiness

# Alternatively, run this 
sysctl -w vm.swappiness=10

# Verify the change
cat /proc/sys/vm/swappiness
10

# Alternatively, verify the change
sysctl vm.swappiness
vm.swappiness = 10

__PERMANENTLY SET SWAPPINESS:__

nano /etc/sysctl.conf
(make sure there is line for vm.swappiness, like example: vm.swappiness = 10)

posts.subject: Sea water levels rising due to global warming
posts.body:
Found any interesting reports, scientific study on this topic?

Why it is problem?
"Sea level rise, driven by increasing global temperatures, will increase the frequency of coastal flooding, storm surges, and salt water intrusion into coastal water bodies and aquifers." ([source](https://www.arcgis.com/apps/MapSeries/index.html?appid=3805293158d54846a29f750d63c6890e))

Interesting sites:
http://sealevel.climatecentral.org

On the image is the 2013 released IPCC estimated global mean sea level rise in 21st century, source: "[Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis](https://ipcc.ch/report/ar5/wg1/)"

Ten per cent of the world's population live in coastal areas that are less than 10 metres (33 ft) above sea level. Furthermore, two thirds of the world's cities with over five million people are located in these low-lying coastal areas. ([source](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0956247807076960))
posts.files: [{"name":"Climate Change 2013 The Physical Science Basis - sea level rise 21st century - FigSPM-09.jpg","thumb":"3547fc8f242713473756d12c21d1d9141b338f52-thumb.jpg","size":474146,"type":"image/jpeg","original":"3547fc8f242713473756d12c21d1d9141b338f52.jpg","directory":"1DJEfWgdJ3rGnqCrKwLrBdQGodRaEBkAry"}]

posts.body:
In 2017, the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) published a Technical Report entitled [Global and Regional Sea Level Rise Scenarios for the United States](https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/techrpt83_Global_and_Regional_SLR_Scenarios_for_the_US_final.pdf).

“In order to bound the set of GMSL rise scenarios for year 2100, we assessed the most up-to-date scientific literature on scientifically supported upper-end GMSL projections, including recent observational and modeling literature related to the potential for rapid ice melt in Greenland and Antarctica. We recommend a revised ‘extreme’ upper-bound scenario for GMSL rise of 2.5 m by the year 2100. [We] revise Parris et al. (2012)’s estimate of the lower bound upward by 0.1 m to 0.3 m by the year 2100.” [NOAA, 2017, p. vi]

(image is from page 32)

posts.subject: Linux, i know how to check open TCP and UDP port, but some UDP's does not return any status
posts.body:
How can i reliably check on Linux if remote server has UDP port open?

I see it works for TCP:
[admin@automation-server 1.2.2]# nc -v -z -w2 192.168.194.4 6443
Connection to 192.168.194.4 6443 port [tcp/sun-sr-https] succeeded!

It also works when i check remote OpenVPN server UDP port:
nc -vz -u 1.2.3.4 1194
Connection to 1.2.3.4 1194 port [udp/openvpn] succeeded!

But it does NOT work (shows no output) when i check Zeronet fileserver port of my remote ZeroNet server with public IP:
(i am sure port is correct, i check it on the top of server's ZeroHello which shows OPENED there)

I am guessing the UDP ports can have different characteristics. What is the way to discover all UDP port status from within remote server?

UPDATE: if anyone want to try (i am not on Linux atm), someone suggests commands like this:
cat /dev/tcp/host/port
cat /dev/udp/host/port
So for example, may be combined like this:
cat /dev/{tcp,udp}/1.2.3.4/22

>>e6077ec2-dadd-45ed-9248-ebb9b009396e
it can not be much better 👌

>>b64f0706-bcae-4268-9b0b-cc9cc2a96116

posts.subject: World Scientists' Warning  to Humanity
posts.body:
World Scientists' Warning  to Humanity - 1992

Sources:
https://www.ucsusa.org/about/1992-world-scientists.html
http://scientistswarning.forestry.oregonstate.edu/sites/sw/files/Ripple_et_al_11-3-17%20Scientists%20main%20text.pdf - English/French/Spanish - contains some more details/references on which scientists base their claims
http://www.scientistswarning.org/ - apparently official page
_ _ _ _ 

Some 1,700 of the world's leading scientists, including the majority of Nobel laureates in the sciences, issued this appeal in November 1992. The World Scientists' Warning to Humanity was written and spearheaded by the late Henry Kendall, former chair of UCS's board of directors. 

Human beings and the natural world are on a collision course. Human activities inflict harsh and often irreversible damage on the environment and on critical resources. If not checked, many of our current practices put at serious risk the future that we wish for human society and the plant and animal kingdoms, and may so alter the living world that it will be unable to sustain life in the manner that we know. Fundamental changes are urgent if we are to avoid the collision our present course will bring about. 

Five inextricably linked areas must be addressed simultaneously:

-    We must bring environmentally damaging activities under control to restore and protect the integrity of the earth's systems we depend on.

    We must, for example, move away from fossil fuels to more benign, inexhaustible energy sources to cut greenhouse gas emissions and the pollution of our air and water. Priority must be given to the development of energy sources matched to Third World needs—small-scale and relatively easy to implement.

    We must halt deforestation, injury to and loss of agricultural land, and the loss of terrestrial and marine plant and animal species.

-    We must manage resources crucial to human welfare more effectively.

    We must give high priority to efficient use of energy, water, and other materials, including expansion of conservation and recycling.

-    We must stabilize population.

-    We must reduce and eventually eliminate poverty.

-    We must ensure sexual equality, and guarantee women control over their own reproductive decisions.

_ _ _ _ 

Scientists’ Warning: 2nd Notice (2017)

[Source #1](https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article/67/12/1026/4605229)
[Source #2](http://scientistswarning.forestry.oregonstate.edu/sites/sw/files/Warning_article_with_supp_11-13-17.pdf)

"Since 1992, with the exception of stabilizing the stratospheric ozone layer, humanity has failed to make sufficient progress in generally solving these foreseen environmental challenges, and alarmingly, most of them are getting far worse (figure 1, file S1). Especially troubling is the current trajectory of potentially catastrophic climate change due to rising GHGs from burning fossil fuels (Hansen et al. 2013), deforestation (Keenan et al. 2015), and agricultural production—particularly from farming ruminants for meat consumption (Ripple et al. 2014). Moreover, we have unleashed a mass extinction event, the sixth in roughly 540 million years"

"As most political leaders respond to pressure, scientists, media influencers, and lay citizens must insist that their governments take immediate action as a moral imperative to current and future generations of human and other life. With a groundswell of organized grassroots efforts, dogged opposition can be overcome and political leaders compelled to do the right thing. It is also time to re-examine and change our individual behaviors, including limiting our own reproduction (ideally to replacement level at most) and drastically diminishing our per capita ­consumption of fossil fuels, meat, and other resources."

"We have learned much since 1992, but the advancement of urgently needed changes in environmental policy, human behavior, and global inequities is still far from sufficient."

"To prevent widespread misery and catastrophic biodiversity loss, humanity must practice a more environmentally sustainable alternative to business as usual. This prescription was well articulated by the world's leading scientists 25 years ago, but in most respects, we have not heeded their warning. Soon it will be too late to shift course away from our failing trajectory, and time is running out. We must recognize, in our day-to-day lives and in our governing institutions, that Earth with all its life is our only home."

When someone get into ones account and steal the all the data, it is a problem, but rather problem of the user (bad password, lack of 2FA) and the company (bad login protection system) and maybe also the directive problem, but certainly not like it is depicted that it is only the directive problem.

And this saying is wrong/false i think:
"but is a useful reminder that, contrary to what many GDPR supporters will tell you, the GDPR itself doesn't actually do much to "protect" your privacy"

[Here is explained](https://ec.europa.eu/justice/smedataprotect/index_en.htm#target-4) (including links to a dirrective) on which new obligations companies has to help user be better aware about their rights, and posibilities to change, remove, or not consent with their data processing.

[And here FAQ for the citizens](https://ec.europa.eu/info/law/law-topic/data-protection/reform/rights-citizens) on how EU data protection is useful to them.

> dangers of moving copyright enforcement down the stack, away from the actual hosting companies deeper and deeper into infrastructure

> by passing off the policing function to infrastructure players rather than the actual (potential) infringers and their hosts, all they have is the nuclear option of completely removing sites from the internet

agree that this is not good, [in EU, the copyright directive](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1528386725_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/+EU+Copyright+directive+Risk+of+censorship+and+limiting+free+flow+of+the+information+in+EU+2016+2019) is getting close to its final form that will be voted upon in the parliament.

posts.subject: Easy way to launch bash script on boot?
posts.body:
__Easy way to launch bash script on boot?__

Hello,

as a root, i did "chmod +x /root/script.sh"
then "crontab -e"
append lines:
@reboot /usr/bin/python /home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/zeronet.py &
@reboot /bin/bash /root/script.sh &

/bin/bash exist (i did "which bash"). First script (zeronet.py) was run, but second one i think not and "Access time" of the script shows a few days back and i booted today, + same script not run even i run it periodicaly, not @reboot 

~# stat /root/script.sh
  File: '/root/script.sh'
  Size: 427             Blocks: 8          IO Block: 4096   regular file
Device: 90e7h/37095d    Inode: 55052473    Links: 1
Access: (0711/-rwx--x--x)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (    0/    root)
Access: 2018-12-31 21:38:36.322903280 -0500
Modify: 2018-12-31 21:37:41.915163583 -0500
Change: 2018-12-31 21:37:41.915163583 -0500
 Birth: -

# stat /home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/zeronet.py
  File: '/home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/zeronet.py'
  Size: 2770            Blocks: 8          IO Block: 4096   regular file
Device: 90e7h/37095d    Inode: 55575371    Links: 1
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (    0/    root)
Access: 2018-12-31 11:32:52.135361416 -0500
Modify: 2018-12-30 09:49:57.187996672 -0500
Change: 2018-12-30 09:49:57.187996672 -0500
 Birth: -

I also tried "chmod 744". Any idea please?

>>b21e6197-177c-4a30-823a-ea91631d397a
Thank you, i think what works is to append new line:
@reboot /root/script.sh &
to the "crontab -e"
and run:
chmod 755 /root/script.sh
chmod +x /root/script.sh

posts.body:
November 2018 - [Bill Nye: We are not going to live on Mars, let alone turn it into Earth](https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/science/2018/11/19/bill-nye-mars-were-not-going-live-there-make-like-earth/1905447002/)

The famous science educator and CEO of The Planetary Society appears on National Geographic Channel's series "MARS." While the series explores human beings living on the Red Planet and even mining it, that doesn't mean Nye buys into the idea.

For starters, he points to Antarctica, where scientists are stationed even during the harsh winter months but no one lives permanently. "Nobody goes to Antarctica to raise a family. You don't go there and build a park, there's just no such thing."

"Nobody's gonna go settle on Mars to raise a family and have generations of Martians," Nye said. "It's not reasonable because it's so cold. And there is hardly any water. There's absolutely no food, and the big thing, I just remind these guys, there's nothing to breathe."

posts.subject: Tor & Zeronet VPS gets shutdown because "10xxx UNREPLIED conntrack sessions"
posts.body:
Hi,

my provider told me their overload prevention system is shutting down my VPS from time to time because of like 10 000 unreplied CONNTRACK connections.

On the server is running Zeronet and Tor relay. So i not known how to kill these connections or what causing them, when i check (netstat -penta) i see reasonable number like tens or couple of hundred).

My search not resulted in any iptables rule or /etc/tor/torrc configurable option that would reduce number of connections made so i created the /root/netlog script:

#!/bin/bash
while true;do
sleep 10
netstat -penta > "netlog.log"
count="$(grep -c . netlog.log)"
if (( "$count" > "1000" ));then
cp -f netlog.log netloglarge.log
fi
if (( "$count" > "5000" ));then
cp -f netlog.log netloghuge.log
service networking restart
fi
done

I am running it on background by launching it @reboot/boot (using "crontab -e")
The crontab line i append is in my case:
@reboot /bin/bash /root/netlog &

Script has 755 permission. (chmod 755 /root/netlog)

Unsure if script will work good. It should allow me to see the connections and apps that made them before the VPS was rebooted

I think most developed music project (currently not actively developed) is [ZeroLSTN](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MQveQ3RPpimXX2wjW2geAGkNJ1GdXkvJ3)
Some other sites at [zerowiki](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:zite-list-media)

>>32b217b3-d8fc-4c07-a3e7-60b51b705318
i am having it, so i think it should be only matter of time until your ZN download it.. (if ZN works good and you clicked the Seed all button under the arrow in the post header). You can also find that images on [different board](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1G1JtVmmo9SqQ3Qxtiq8QWbpTsSZvzaR2B:nigri:e1622c64-15d6-4e39-b142-2044b5afb172).

You can try to duck.com the IP to discover some details, but i do not think it can help you discover exact house, flat or even PC or even person which used the PC at the time of the theft. Also some people use proxies (intermediary remotely rented computer) which means their IP is different from their real location IP. If you have solid evidence, consider hand over it to the police.

posts.subject: 'Our house is on fire': Greta Thunberg, 16, urges leaders to act on climate
posts.body:
January 2019, Switzerland, Davos World Economic Forum

"Here in Davos – just like everywhere else – everyone is talking about money. It seems money and growth are our only main concerns.

And since the climate crisis has never once been treated as a crisis, people are simply not aware of the full consequences on our everyday life.

....

We must change almost everything in our current societies. The bigger your carbon footprint, the bigger your moral duty. The bigger your platform, the bigger your responsibility.

Adults keep saying: “We owe it to the young people to give them hope.” But I don’t want your hope. I don’t want you to be hopeful. I want you to panic. I want you to feel the fear I feel every day. And then I want you to act.

I want you to act as you would in a crisis. I want you to act as if our house is on fire. Because it is."

[source](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/jan/25/our-house-is-on-fire-greta-thunberg16-urges-leaders-to-act-on-climate)

[twitter.com/GretaThunberg](https://twitter.com/GretaThunberg)

posts.subject: Global warming - Why 5 or 9 °C global temperature increase this century is alot?
posts.body:
Just red this interesting quotation from the Andrew Dessler, the professor of Atmospheric Sciences at Texas A&M University [here](https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/gray-matters/amp/green-new-deal-hope-climate-change-13619796.php):

"If we don't take action, unchecked greenhouse-gas emissions would lead to global-average warming over this century of 5 degrees Fahrenheit to 9 degrees Fahrenheit. This may not sound like much until you realize that the warming since the last ice age — a warming that completely reconfigured the planet and caused 300 feet of sea level rise — was about 9 degrees Fahrenheit."

"Don't have kids.  There's no future for them.  Humans are destroying every inch of this planet we touch.  Irrelevant whether you believe in climate change or not, the truth is that we are poisoning this planet.... the soil, the water and the air.  It will be a toxic wasteland by the end of this century..... because Humanity refuses to change the self destructive path we are on.  Enjoy.﻿"

posts.subject: Scrapebox: Layer 7 http DDoS attack on a clearnet web server using paid tool Scrapebox & free public proxies
posts.body:
OUR AIM:
This is a tutorial, concept on how to overload clearnet based web server / website using paid software called Scrapebox (runs under Windows, Mac and Linux (via Wine))

HOW WE DO IT:
We will try to use this software to intitiate and maintain up to 500 page load requests in paralel to a site. It will appear like a hundreds of various visitors at once, thanks to free public proxies (one page load / one IP). Software will query user defined list of URLs from same site to cause the overload of the server and bring the website down.
Overloading third party servers may be illegal in ones country.

BEFORE WE START:
Check that the target is not using Cloudflare dos protection (http://myip.ms). If it is, then maybe this attack will not work, but one can try to query random, non existing subpages or pages with parameters like:
domain.com/existingpage.php?keywords=randomstring
domain.com/randomstring.php?keywords=randomstring
in aim to bypass the cloudflare cache and make it query destination server. When i used the URL parameter - (?keywords=), then cloudflare response headers are "no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate" which i hope means page is not served from cloudflare cache, but the query was made to the target server.

TUTORIAL:
1. Buy and activate Scrapebox - http://www.scrapebox.com/features
2. Create file that contains all URLs of subpages of a target website.
a) one can try domain.com/sitemap.xml / sitemap.php. Scrapebox has sitemap extractor plugin.
b) one can try to discover if the site has search function (which may require more server performance and maybe such requersts will not be cached on the server causing higher impact on server performance), copy the search URL like https://domain.com/search.php?keywords= and use OpenOffice Calc or online tool like https://textmechanic.co/Random-String-Generator.html to append random strings to such URL generating millions of URLs. Maybe good to use search phrases like "a" which requires server to output many results or use spaces "+" in search phrase. Possibly this method is worse than using real addresses from sitemap, because server admin can easier see these are fake request and can distinguish them from real traffic.
One can use OpenOffice Calc to create such list.
3. fill some name, e-mail and website in the Fast Poster area of the Scrapebox. No need to enter multiple because it will be only used if it finds Wordpress comment form (not needed in this case because we will likely not try to overload blog site? we just need to load target website causing load to the server)
4. harvest proxies using Scrapebox built-in free proxy harvester (you should get hundreds of anonymouse proxies)
5. In the Scrapebox / Settings / Connections... set Fast poster connection count to the maximum (when i tried 150 connections, it used only maybe 100 webserver connections at a time on my Apache server with Varnish cache, regular Apache max. concurrent connections is 200)
For 500 concurrent connections (Scrapebox maximum) i think one have to have maybe thousands of proxies, else too many concurrent connections from one IP may trigger target server firewall rules and block proxy IPs temporarily for like a hour a day or so.

USEFUL TOOLS:
https://textmechanic.co/ (randomization, deduplication, sorting, counter, permutations, search & replace...)
https://www.browserling.com/tools/extract-urls
thank you. keep zeronet open a few days to seed the content if possible

posts.subject: Debug cause of HDD/low RAM Linux lag?
posts.body:
Hello,

it seems that from time to time (every like a minute or almost permanently at some point) Linux 4.15.0* Debian computer has problem with moving mouse cursor or playing computer game fluently. Then after like 10 seconds it continue being fluent again. During the issue i am watching CPU usage graph and it is not maxed out. Also RAM has some space, though not much. I am watching disk activity using htop sorting by IO_RATE column and also using "iotop -ao" command. But that do not give me clue about which app causing this lag. It shows several processes with over 1 MB/s transfer, but that does not mean any of these is the cause.

There is primary HDD and two external HDDs each connected via computer USB 2.0 port.

Which commands or the tool can discover the app that is causing the lag or even function of the app?

Thank you both. Yes, Firefox is big RAM eater here. I think it helped to close / restart it.

My swappiness is 70 (means rather tend to swap; [here is more about swappiness btw](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1MMmEvvdLRNqV6eWCnL5dm3DuS6ELa94pG:linux:39a13015-f72c-4e03-a8a6-14b264757aba)) which i thought is good idea where RAM is scarce resource. I have HDD as a SWAP partition. You think i should decrease the swappiness? The figures on the image is my regular or maybe even a bit under average memory usage).

posts.subject: Investing and Global warming
posts.body: "When forced to bet, investors bet on warming. ... investors still don’t believe the threat will be severe enough to force a sweeping reorganization of modern economies. This might reflect investor pessimism about humanity’s response to climate change, or it might reflect a belief that the warming trend won’t be a world-changing disaster. ... posts.subject: When will AV1 video codec hardware become available?
posts.body:
At the end of September on Videolan Dev Days 2018, Pascal „Skal“ Massimino (Google employee responsible for codecs, Youtube) shown the attached slide that suggests hardware support on mobile (ARM chips) devices is planed on roughly 2020. Later was mentioned that affordable devices with AV1 hardware support maybe 2022.

It seems current hardware does less than 1 frame per second AV1 encoding: https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=27-CPUs-AV1-SVT-Video-Encode
Decoding (playback) should not be that big issue atm.

i think each sucks in each own way.
main advantage of windows is variety of software and support for games and bigger hardware support. Linux is more customizable, better work on command line & tools, less privacy & virus worries. at least how i understand that.

no, i think the person who responded to you said this particular thing wrong

# HOW SEEDING / HOSTING IMAGES ON MILLCHAN ZERONET WORKS

SEEDER: Seeder is a person who has completely downloaded some content (image for example) and he is able to upload it to others. 
PEER: Peer is usually someone who have part and or complete content.

Person who submit new images need to keep zeronet open until at least one person (more is better) download it. It is similar like with torrent. more people download your content, better it is for propagation to others, because it will be unlikely that all at once will turn off computer and the content will become unreachable for others (until one or more seeders go back online).

Some peers have CLOSED PORT (you can see it on the top of [ZeroHello](http://127.0.0.1:43110/)) and not using Tor with Zeronet (again you can see on ZeroHello) then it can be a problem for other people (peers) to download content from them, because maybe themself have closed port and no Tor and i believe 2 peers with closed ports can not interconnect each other. So that is why it is good to seed to couple of people to ensure content become "well seeded". Some people setup [nonstop running zeronet computers(servers)](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16Go5kc2U9Ff4jeaY8kYiDEgpMYdgyboPY/?Topic:2_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+Install+and+run+Zeronet+on+a+Raspberry+Pi+or+any+Linux+computer) to host the content non stop.

One way to DISCOVER HOW MANY PEOPLE ALREADY DOWNLOADED YOUR IMAGES is to go to [ZeroHello and click "Files" link](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/?Files).
Maybe check /dev/ board and ask @mcdev if he can add feature which will show number of peers of the already downloaded images. (partialy downloaded images show it).

posts.subject: Block zeronet upload via Linux iptables?
posts.body:
Hello, i am thinking how one can temporarily block all uploads to other zeronet peers while allowing download from them?
This can come handy when one is temporarily on slow internet.

Following rule is good in case ones INPUT chain policy is DROP:
iptables -A INPUT -m state --state ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
it should allow all incoming connections that are a reply to outgoing connections i initiated. But should not allow incoming connections initiated by remote peers or any remote IP at all.
Maybe the rule i want will need to be targetted to the fileserver port of the zeronet?

iptables -A INPUT -dport fileserverportnumberhere -m state --state NEW -j DROP

following rule would be used if default INPUT policy is ACCEPT.

i do not know

- - - - - - - - -

CUrrently my work-in-progress iptables export file looks like this:
# Generated by iptables-save v1.6.0 on Tue Apr 30 20:37:32 2019
*filter
:INPUT DROP [4463:495891]
:FORWARD ACCEPT [0:0]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [137169:309203495]
-A INPUT -m state --state RELATED,ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -p icmp -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -p tcp -m tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -p tcp -m multiport --dports 9050:9051 -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -s myvpnserverip1/32 -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -s myvpnserverip2/32 -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT -s myvpnserverip3/32 -j ACCEPT
COMMIT
# Completed on Tue Apr 30 20:37:32 2019

These rules SHOULD block every connection initiated from external IPs with following exceptions:
- not from 3 defined IPs of mine
- allow all connections that are icmp - ping
- all that go to port 22 (ssh)
- those that are result/reply initiated from local server (RELATED,ESTABLISHED)
- will not block 9050 and 5051 ports which are Tor - without that, somehow Tor was marked as Timeout on ZeroHello.

How to export iptables:
iptables-save > /etc/ipt
How to import iptables:
iptables-restore < /etc/ipt
How to restore iptables custom rules at boot, open /etc/network/interfaces and under line "iface eth0 inet static" add new line:
pre-up iptables-restore < /etc/ipt

posts.subject: Simple explanation by Telegram on what is DDoS attack, how it works
posts.body:
[clearnet (Twitter) source](https://twitter.com/durov/status/1138942773430804480)

"A DDoS is a “Distributed Denial of Service attack”: your servers get GADZILLIONS of garbage requests which stop them from processing legitimate requests. Imagine that an army of lemmings just jumped the queue at McDonald’s in front of you – and each is ordering a whopper.

The server is busy telling the whopper lemmings they came to the wrong place – but there are so many of them that the server can’t even see you to try and take your order.

To generate these garbage requests, bad guys use “botnets” made up of computers of unsuspecting users which were infected with malware at some point in the past. This makes a DDoS similar to the zombie apocalypse: one of the whopper lemmings just might be your grandpa.

There’s a bright side: All of these lemmings are there just to overload the servers with extra work – they can’t take away your BigMac and coke. Your data is safe."

There is no issue using one identity when you are kept anonymous using Tor or a VPN (not so bulletproof possibly for all cases). Even if you do not use Tor and use zeronet as is, you are probably anonymous as there was not yet described any method to match certain peer to a certain user:
ZeroTalk topic [Is it possible to get the IP address of a certain user?](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1549637074_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm)
ZeroTalk topic [Explanation on how updates are published to peers](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1526907663_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS#comment_317_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di) (you can not know if the peer from which you have received the update is the user who caused the update or if it is just a peer who received the update from the user and so on)

>>3a86e6c1-fb40-4b31-ab0d-93e71dce191e
millchan id (one that is generated for you onsite) is already anonymous and can not be tracked to your IP per my knowledge.

but less features at this time :(
wondering if admin migrate or add features

posts.subject: Friendship, good social relations improve health
posts.body:
"Friendship, good social relations and strong supportive networks improve health at home, at work and in the community."

"Belonging to a social network of communication and mutual obligation makes people feel cared for, loved, esteemed and valued."

"Social isolation and exclusion are associated with increased rates of premature death and poorer chances of survival after a heart attack (Fig. 6). People who get less social and emotional support from others are more likely to experience less well-being, more depression, a greater risk of pregnancy complications and higher levels of disability from chronic diseases. In addition, bad close relationships can lead to poor mental and physical health."

Source: [who.int](http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/98438/e81384.pdf)

Fig. 6. (image) sources:

Berkman LF, Syme SL. Social networks, host resistance and mortality: a nine year follow-up of Alameda County residents. American Journal of Epidemiology, 1979, 109:186–204.

Hsieh CC, Pugh MD. Poverty, income inequality, and violent crime: a meta-analysis of recent aggregate data studies. Criminal Justice Review, 1993, 18:182–202.

Kaplan GA et al. Social connections and mortality from all causes and from cardiovascular disease: prospective evidence from eastern Finland. American Journal of Epidemiology, 1988, 128:370–380.

Kawachi I et al. A prospective study of social networks in relation to total mortality and cardiovascular disease in men in the USA. Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, 1996, 50(3):245–251.

Oxman TE et al. Social support and depressive symptoms in the elderly. American Journal of Epidemiology, 1992, 135:356–368.

Sampson RJ, Raudenbush SW, Earls F. Neighborhoods and violent crime: a multilevel study of collective efficacy. Science, 1997, 277:918–924.

Source of Fig. 6: House JS, Landis KR, Umberson D. Social relationships and health. Science, 1988, 241:540–545.

= = = = = =

Suggestions for lonely or socially isolated adults have included taking a class, getting a dog, doing volunteer work and joining a senior center.

posts.subject: Help seed this zite
posts.body:
Zeronet sites needs peers in order to be accessible at all times and updates to it well propagated.
Help seed the sites and if you have alot of space, you may also seed all site optional files like images (drag the site corner button to the left).
Some people enable Tor for all connections (On the top of the zeroHello) in order to keep anonymous when seeding questionable files.
[ZeroWorld](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1K3zGnsgcppi47PMdpLAVj2t79s3D7viEX) (ZeroTalk clone by everybody@zeroid.bit) - http://127.0.0.1:43110/1K3zGnsgcppi47PMdpLAVj2t79s3D7viEX

@mcdev Is it good idea (performance-wise especialy) to allow users to hide/mute particular discussion threads? I am a bit missing this. Someone put offtopic/bad thread into the board which obviously has no moderator.

Isn't spoiler meant for sensitive images so the visitor does not automaticaly download thumbnail he do not want to host? It may be good if the option has a info box (mouse hover) saying like: Sensitive image? Do not show thumbnail, only a placeholder icon.

>>f28dcb3b-e4be-4fee-b1f8-e09fbc9d8f24
seems not to be seeded, not loading

>>82956d09-da00-4809-bb86-339fe41e1112
yes, CPU single threading is the issue, in that regards if the seeder plan to seed many sites/files and also use the server to browse the sites, it is good the CPU thread is fast not some low end RaspberryPi 2 or 3. Raspberry Pi 4 USB data throughput should be up to 300MB/s where Rpi 2, 3 are 30MB/s or less. For 3000 sites, zeronet [was seen](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1565037100_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS#comment_92_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez9NJJ4) to consume 1GB RAM.
I think for the seedbox, the SSD drive is not needed. Rather high capacity drive. In my country i can buy maximum 5TB external drive in 2.5" format. 3.5" drives are a bit cheaper and i seen 16TB capacity drive from Seagate, but are more noisy and possibly double power consumption.

[Here are](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16Go5kc2U9Ff4jeaY8kYiDEgpMYdgyboPY/?Topic:2_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+Install+and+run+Zeronet+on+a+Raspberry+Pi+or+any+Linux+computer) some tips on zeronet installation aimed for people who want to run seedbox.

posts.subject: Too many P2P apps, too high CPU load. Dead end, what now?
posts.body:
Hi,

my P2P apps and Firefox utilizing 20% of the CPU each and it is hitting 100% in total quite often. Can not upgrade CPU on current computer. Will not be buying new desktop computer (too big and no power efficiency). I am thinking what are my options. I realy like this computer. It is good performing, it has nicely customized Windows that i do not want to loose.

I can continue using it for my P2P apps, but not Firefox browsing. (i would remove 20% load)
But Firefox needs to be at same place as P2P apps, because when searching for the content to DL,  i want to be on same computer where are P2P apps, right?
So i have to move only one (or later two) P2P apps to other computer.
It seems like zeronet and qbittorrent is the main CPU hog. When i would move the P2P app, i would loose access to the storage device that other P2P apps using on my current PC.

The main PC is Windows. If new, secondary PC is Linux, how i can get access to the external HDD that is attached to my other Windows PC?

I can be moving ZeroNet P2P app possibly, because other P2P apps are not tied to its data. I would then need to somehow in Firefox setup kind of forwarding that would redirect 127.0.0.1:43110 to my new LAN based Linux computer with ZeroNet.. (i would not use my zeronet pc IP as zeronet links sometimes still contains 127.0.0.1 IP specifically)  Any idea how i would do this forwarding on Windows and Firefox PC? In Firefox? In hosts file? In Windows Firewall?

The new, zeronet PC would have to be energy efficient ad with high performance for one CPU thread (as [zeronet utilize only 1 thread apparently](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1565037100_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS#comment_92_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez9NJJ4)), this seems complicated

Any flaws in my approach? Ideas?

posts.subject: BTC = 0.03-0.06% of global energy-related CO2 emissions. ETH, LTC more friendly
posts.body:
"Recent published estimates of bitcoin’s electricity consumption are wide-ranging, on the order of 20‑80 TWh annually, or about 0.1-0.3% of global electricity use"
https://www.iea.org/newsroom/news/2019/july/bitcoin-energy-use-mined-the-gap.html

"bitcoin mining is likely responsible for 10‑20 Mt CO2 per year, or 0.03-0.06% of global energy-related CO2 emissions."
(as of November 2018)
"The corresponding annual carbon emissions range from 22.0 to 22.9 MtCO2 ... This level sits between the levels produced by the nations of Jordan and Sri Lanka"
https://www.iea.org/newsroom/news/2019/july/bitcoin-energy-use-mined-the-gap.html
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2542435119302557

"Ethereum (ETH), the second largest cryptocurrency by market value, processes more than twice as many transactions as the bitcoin network while using only about one-third of the electricity consumed by bitcoin. ETH also operates on a Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus mechanism"
https://www.iea.org/newsroom/news/2019/july/bitcoin-energy-use-mined-the-gap.html

"From 1 January 2016 to 30 June 2018, we estimate that mining Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin and Monero consumed an average of 17, 7, 7 and 14 MJ to generate one US$, respectively. Comparatively, conventional mining of aluminium, copper, gold, platinum and rare earth oxides consumed 122, 4, 5, 7 and 9 MJ to generate one US$, respectively, indicating that (with the exception of aluminium) cryptomining consumed more energy than mineral mining to produce an equivalent market value."
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41893-018-0152-7

posts.subject: Libra cryptocurrency
posts.body:
"This is the goal for Libra: A stable currency built on a secure and stable open-source blockchain, backed by a reserve of real assets, and governed by an independent association."

"Unlike the majority of cryptocurrencies, Libra is fully backed by a reserve of real assets. A basket of bank deposits and short-term government securities will be held in the Libra Reserve for every Libra that is created, building trust in its intrinsic value. ... The Libra Association is an independent, not-for-profit membership organization headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland." ([source](https://libra.org/en-US/white-paper/))

"for new Libra coins to be created, there must be an equivalent purchase of Libra for fiat and transfer of that fiat to the reserve ... The reserve will be invested in low-risk assets that will yield interest over time. ... The reserve will be held by a geographically distributed network of custodians with investment-grade credit rating to limit counterparty risk." ([source](https://libra.org/en-US/about-currency-reserve/#the_reserve))

[Founding members](https://libra.org/en-US/association/#founding_members): Visa, Mastercard, Paypal, Ebay, Facebook/Calibra, Uber, Vodafone..

"It will use the [proof-of-stake consensus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_of_stake)"

"The Libra blockchain testnet will be launched at the end of 2019, and the mainnet will be deployed by 2020."

posts.subject: Risks of storing money on blockchain and using cryptocurrencies
posts.body:
[This article](https://www.wired.com/story/theres-no-good-reason-to-trust-blockchain-technology/) was linked from the [Ethereum website](https://www.ethereum.org/learn/#critique-and-skepticism) and it shows interesting information that blockchain may not be as secure and safe storage as some may think:

"What blockchain does is shift some of the trust in people and institutions to trust in technology. You need to trust the cryptography, the protocols, the software, the computers and the network. And you need to trust them absolutely, because they’re often single points of failure.

When that trust turns out to be misplaced, there is no recourse. If your bitcoin exchange gets hacked, you lose all of your money. If your bitcoin wallet gets hacked, you lose all of your money. If you forget your login credentials, you lose all of your money. If there’s a bug in the code of your smart contract, you lose all of your money. If someone successfully hacks the blockchain security, you lose all of your money. In many ways, trusting technology is harder than trusting people. Would you rather trust a human legal system or the details of some computer code you don’t have the expertise to audit?
...
People have to trust the software and the operating systems and the computers everything is running on. And we've seen attacks against wallets and exchanges. We’ve seen Trojans and phishing and password guessing. Criminals have even used flaws in the system that people use to repair their cell phones to steal bitcoin.
...
Moreover, in any distributed trust system, there are backdoor methods for centralization to creep back in. With bitcoin, there are only a few miners of consequence. There’s one company that provides most of the mining hardware."

posts.subject: VPN vs Tor - its privacy and anonymity
posts.body:
VPN vs Tor

    _VPN_ is faster than Tor, and is suitable for P2P downloading. The major downside (and reason VPN is said to provide privacy rather than anonymity) is that it requires you trust your VPN provider. This is because, should it wish to (or is compelled to), your VPN provider can “see” what you get up to on the internet. VPN also allows you to easily spoof your geographic location.

    _Tor_ is much slower, is often blocked by websites, and is not suitable for P2P, but it does not require that you trust anybody, and is therefore much more truly anonymous.

posts.subject: Carbon dioxide concentrations in the Earth's atmosphere (past and future)
posts.body: Graphs from studies about past, current and future CO2 concentrations in the Earth's atmosphere.

posts.subject: Last 400 thousand years CO2
posts.body:
This figure shows the variations in concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere during the last 400 thousand years.

Since the Industrial Revolution, circa 1900, the burning of fossil fuels has caused a dramatic increase of CO2 in the atmosphere, reaching levels unprecedented in the last 400 thousand years. This increase has been implicated as a primary cause of global warming. 

Source and the data for this graph [here](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Carbon_Dioxide_400kyr.png)

"This graph, based on the comparison of atmospheric samples contained in ice cores and more recent direct measurements, provides evidence that atmospheric CO2 has increased since the Industrial Revolution. (Credit: Luthi, D., et al.. 2008; Etheridge, D.M., et al. 2010; Vostok ice core data/J.R. Petit et al.; NOAA Mauna Loa CO2 record.)

Revolution. (Credit: Luthi, D., et al.. 2008; Etheridge, D.M., et al. 2010; Vostok ice core data/J.R. Petit et al.; NOAA Mauna Loa CO2 record.) Find out more about ice cores (external site)."

"The Earth's climate has changed throughout history. Just in the last 650,000 years there have been seven cycles of glacial advance and retreat, with the abrupt end of the last ice age about 7,000 years ago marking the beginning of the modern climate era — and of human civilization. Most of these climate changes are attributed to very small variations in Earth’s orbit that change the amount of solar energy our planet receives.

    Scientific evidence for warming of the climate system is unequivocal.
    - Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.1"

1.
"IPCC Fifth Assessment Report, [Summary for Policymakers](https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2018/02/AR5_SYR_FINAL_SPM.pdf)

B.D. Santer et.al., “A search for human influences on the thermal structure of the atmosphere,” Nature vol 382, 4 July 1996, 39-46

Gabriele C. Hegerl, “Detecting Greenhouse-Gas-Induced Climate Change with an Optimal Fingerprint Method,” Journal of Climate, v. 9, October 1996, 2281-2306

V. Ramaswamy et.al., “Anthropogenic and Natural Influences in the Evolution of Lower Stratospheric Cooling,” Science 311 (24 February 2006), 1138-1141

B.D. Santer et.al., “Contributions of Anthropogenic and Natural Forcing to Recent Tropopause Height Changes,” Science vol. 301 (25 July 2003), 479-483."

source: [nasa.gov](https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/)
posts.subject: Last 800 thousand years CO2
Can government break encryption 128/256bit?
posts.body:
Interesting posts i have found:
1. [Time and energy required to brute-force a AES-256 encryption key.](https://www.reddit.com/r/theydidthemath/comments/1x50xl/time_and_energy_required_to_bruteforce_a_aes256/)
2. [Is it possible to break a 128-bit key?](https://stackoverflow.com/a/4390130)

quoting:
1. "1 billion gpus @ 2 gigaflops each (2 billion flops) ... It would take ~6.7e40 times longer than the age of the universe to exhaust half of the keyspace of a AES-256 key. ... 1 billion GPUs would require 150 nuclear power plant reactors to constantly power them, and it would still take longer than the age of the universe to exhaust half of a AES-256 keyspace."
2. "Cracking one 128 bit key, today (June/2017) costs approx. 1e-17 * 2^128 = 3.5e+21
This would take 2^128 / (5e18*3.14e7) = 2.1e12 years with bitcoin mining system."

posts.subject: How government internet data interception works (UK and South Africa is doing that)
posts.body:
The source is [this](https://privacyinternational.org/long-read/3164/two-states-admit-bulk-interception-practices-why-does-it-matter) article.

quoting:

Six years after NSA contractor Edward Snowden leaked documents providing details about how states' mass surveillance programmes function, two states – the UK and South Africa – publicly admit using bulk interception capabilities.
how bulk interception works inforgraphic

Both governments have been conducting bulk interception of internet traffic by tapping undersea fibre optic cables landing in the UK and South Africa respectively in secret for years.

Both admissions came during and as a result of legal proceedings brought by Privacy International and other civil society actors challenging ­– among others – these interception capabilities.

The European Court of Human Rights also recently highlighted that “a system of secret surveillance for the protection of national security may undermine or even destroy democracy under the cloak of defending it.”

Two courts in two far ends of the globe – one in the North and the other in the South – have now the opportunity to prohibit bulk surveillance practices and ensure that our privacy is protected. The Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights and the South African High Court in Pretoria have an opportunity to declare that bulk interception of internet traffic is a serious violation of the right to privacy.

To be continued…

posts.subject: Firefox - how to stay private with this browser?
posts.body:
Do you know any good tutorial on how to make Firefox more private browser?

I have found [this](https://web.archive.org/web/20180821224202/https://jojo-website.neocities.org/privacy.html) article, so i am pasting its contents here:

firefox "about:config" settings

    type about:config in the url bar and press enter.
    Press the button that says "I'll be careful, I promise!"

change the following settings below:

>    privacy.firstparty.isolate = true
        this preference isolates all browser identifier sources (e.g. cookies) to the first party domain, with the goal of preventing tracking across different domains(thanks to the tor uplift project)
>    privacy.resistFingerprinting = true
        this preference makes Firefox more resistant to browser fingerprinting(thanks to the tor uplift project).
>    browser.urlbar.speculativeConnect.enabled = false
        Disable preloading of autocomplete URLs.
>    media.navigator.enabled = false
        Websites can track the microphone and camera status of your device
>    privacy.trackingprotection.enabled = true
        this enables the firefox built in tracking protection.
>    geo.enabled = false
        disables the browser geolocation feature.
>    network.cookie.cookieBehavior = 1
        this setting tells your browser handle cookies a certain way
        0 = All types of cookies are accepted
        1 = only accept cookies from the website you are on and block any third party cookies
        2 = makes your browser block all cookies
>    network.cookie.lifetimePolicy = 2
        this settings tells your browser how long cookies are kept
        0 = the default way the browser accepts cookies
        1 = prompt for how to treat each cookie
        2 = accept cookie for this session only
        3 = accept for a number of days you specify
>    browser.cache.offline.enable = false
        Disables offline cache.
>    browser.send_pings = false
        This setting disables letting the website see what you clicked on.
>    dom.battery.enabled = false
        this setting disables the website from seeing how much battery life your computer has.
>    webgl.disabled = true
        you should disable webgl because it is a security risk
>    browser.sessionstore.max_tabs_undo = 0
        Even with Firefox set to not remember history, your closed tabs are stored temporarily at Menu -> History -> Recently Closed Tabs.
>    dom.storage.enabled = false
        disables client-side session and persistent storage
>    privacy.donottrackheader.enabled = true
        sends a "do not track" request to the website your on
>    camera.control.face_detection.enabled = false
        disables face detection if webcam is on
>    device.sensors.enabled = false
        disables access to device related information
>    dom.netinfo.enabled = false
        this setting disables giving away any network info
>    beacon.enabled = false
        disables webpages to send data to a web server prior to the unloading of the document
>    browser.safebrowsing.enabled = false
        disables google safe browsing and phishing protection. Security risk, but privacy improvement
>    browser.safebrowsing.malware.enabled = false
        disables google safe browsing malware checks.security risk, but privacy improvement
>    dom.enable_user_timing
        disables user timing api
>    dom.enable_resource_timing
        disables resource timing api

WebRTC about:config settings:

>    media.peerconnection.enabled = false
>    media.peerconnection.turn.disable = true
>    media.peerconnection.use_document_iceservers = false
>    media.peerconnection.video.enabled = false
>    media.peerconnection.identity.timeout = 1

firefox addons
here are some good addons to improve privacy

>    ublock origin
        a really good adblocker and content filter
>    https everywhere
        this addon encrypts your communication with the https protocol, with the S meaning secure
>    decentraleyes
        this addon blocks content delivery networks and emulates them for added privacy
>    noscript
        disables javascript on pages you don't trust and you can add exceptions
>    umatrix
        like ublock and noscript combined but better
>    smart https
        makes sites use https(if they have it)
>    cookie auto delete
        deletes cookies when you close a tab in the browser

posts.subject: Pale Moon
posts.body:
It may possibly be faster to use [Pale Moon](https://www.palemoon.org/) instead of Firefox as its spyware level is [claimed](https://spyware.neocities.org/guides/palemoon.html) to be lower:
Quoting:
"these settings should be changed in about:config":

Addon Blocklist 	extensions.blocklist.enabled 	False
OCSP querying 	services.sync.prefs.sync.security.OCSP.enabled 	False
OCSP querying 	security.OCSP.GET.enabled 	False
OCSP querying 	security.OCSP.require 	False
OCSP querying 	security.OCSP.enabled 	0
Geolocation 	geo.enabled 	False

Other person [suggests](https://www.howtogeek.com/335712/update-why-you-shouldnt-use-waterfox-pale-moon-or-basilisk/) NOT to use Pale Moon:
"Pale Moon is based on much older code. It won’t have the new web features or performance improvements of modern versions of Firefox, nor does it support watching certain kinds of video with DRM.

More importantly, basing a browser on such old code makes security patches harder. Pale Moon’s developer tries to keep up with Firefox security patches, but he’s maintaining old code that Mozilla has abandoned. Mozilla reportedly has over a thousand employees, while Pale Moon has one primary developer, trying to maintain a huge amount of code that’s becoming increasingly outdated. The older code also omits features that help make modern browsers so secure, like the multi-process sandboxing features that have finally arrived in Firefox Quantum.

Besides, Pale Moon tends to perform worse on browser benchmarks compared to modern browsers, which isn’t surprising given its age."

posts.subject: November 2019 interview with the Ecosia founder
posts.body:
[November, 2019 interview with the Ecosia founder Christian Kroll](https://www.vice.com/amp/en_us/article/mbmde4/this-search-engine-uses-its-profits-to-plant-trees-across-the-world-v26n4), a mild-mannered, 35-year-old German tech entrepreneur.

"trees don’t just help with climate change either, but also with poverty, hunger, flooding, and drought, as well as the biodiversity crisis"

"All Ecosia’s profits are given to partners around the world such as Progreso and the Green Belt Movement, which plant trees on our behalf. They are the experts and know what they’re doing. Recently we’ve planted acacia trees, which are good for drought, in Burkina Faso; fast-growing, protein-rich moringa trees in Peru; and mangrove trees in Madagascar.

We are a small company of just 45 people, and one of our most important teams is our tree-planting officers. Their role is to ensure the tree planting is actually happening and the trees are surviving."

"recently we have become what’s known as a steward-owned company, and it’s now legally irreversible not just to sell Ecosia but also for anyone to take profits out of it."

In September, speaking to heads of state during the U.N. General Assembly, Thunberg pulled no punches: “We are in the beginning of a mass extinction, and all you can talk about is money and fairy tales of eternal economic growth,” she said. “How dare you.”
❤️ but if she is your sister, you would talk opposite? 🤗

Any update? Maybe your zeronet is not running long enough or having too many files to download. On one computer, i am awaiting for image 3 and 5 and on another i see all images.

You can enable Multiuser plugin in [/Plugins](/Plugins) page. Then on the top of the [ZeroHello](/) should be able to switch user IDs. Identities are stored in data/users.json by the way, it is important file to backup. And you can also edit it, preferably when ZN is not running.

If Multiuser will be able to setup multiple identities, then you can replace one identity by your old identity by manually editting the data/users.json file. Then restarting ZN.

inside i can see your MC id: 17q...@millchan
I do not see any way to block user based on this, so i open data.json on above mentioned page. And copy some unique phrase (text of your MC comment) and search it on MC (Sandwich menu top left corner, Search, paste the phrase. Then i can click the arrow and mute the user. User is added to ZN-wide blocking, unblocking can be done on ZeroHello, three dots menu.

=> would be good if ZeroHello, allow more details and actions on an optional file/image.

make sure Zeronet has Tor available, if you can not control the router (in which you could forward port to your LAN IP or set DMZ for your computer), you can purchase an VPN service which is featured to support port forwarding/opening port (you will then define this port number as your [ZN file server port](/Config). Or you can [get a virtual server and setup a VPN yourself and open the port yourself](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1548340010_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+setup+private+OpenVPN+on+a+Linux+server+and+Windows+Android+client).

posts.subject: The reasonings of the wise men are futile.​—1 Cor. 3:20.
posts.body:
Thursday, July 8

The reasonings of the wise men are futile.​—1 Cor. 3:20

In the days of ancient Israel, Satan used false religion to promote immorality. Today, he does the same. False religion tolerates and even promotes immoral conduct. Consequently, many who claim to serve God have abandoned his clear standards of morality. The apostle Paul describes in his letter to the Romans what has been the result. (Rom. 1:28-31) Among “the things not fitting” are all forms of sexual immorality, including homosexuality. (Rom. 1:24-27, 32; Rev. 2:20) How important it is for us to stick to the Bible’s clear teachings! Human philosophy ignores or contradicts God’s righteous standards. It does not nurture the fruitage of God’s spirit but, rather, “the works of the flesh.” (Gal. 5:19-23) It generates pride and arrogance, and the result is that people become “lovers of themselves.” (2 Tim. 3:2-4) These qualities are the opposite of the meek, humble spirit that God’s servants are encouraged to have.​—2 Sam. 22:28. w19.06 5-6 ¶12-14
